title: Skill-Coach Improves Itself: 5 Iterations of Meta-Improvement
description: The skill-coach demonstrates its own principles by improving itself through 5 iterations. Shows progressive disclosure, anti-pattern detection, and the improvement loop it teaches. The ultimate meta-demonstration: a skill using its own guidance to become better.

skills.name: skill_coach
skills.role: Guided its own improvement through 5 iterations, applying anti-pattern detection, progressive disclosure, and temporal knowledge capture to itself

phases.name: Iteration 1: Foundation
phases.outcome: Added 5 skill-specific anti-patterns, Evolution Timeline, Skill Review Checklist, removed non-existent file references

phases.name: Iteration 2: Actionability
phases.outcome: Added 3 Common Workflows, actionable iteration strategy, tool permission explanations

phases.name: Iteration 3: Expert Knowledge
phases.outcome: Added Skill Creation Shibboleths (novice vs expert), enhanced 'What Makes a Great Skill' from 5 to 7 items

phases.name: Iteration 4: Usability
phases.outcome: Added Quick Wins section, simplified structure, description progression (Bad→Better→Good)

phases.name: Iteration 5: Decision Support
phases.outcome: Added Decision Trees (when to create skill, Skill vs Subagent vs MCP), prioritized checklist

outcome.summary: Successfully improved skill-coach through 5 iterations, reducing line count from 482 to 470 while becoming more comprehensive. Achieved 0 validation errors, demonstrating the improvement loop the skill teaches.
learned: Progressive disclosure works: 482→470 lines but MORE comprehensive
Meta-skills can improve themselves using their own guidance
Each iteration should have a clear focus (Foundation, Actionability, Expert Knowledge, Usability, Decision Support)
Anti-patterns are more valuable than templates
Temporal knowledge prevents LLMs from suggesting outdated patterns
Prioritized checklists (CRITICAL/HIGH/NICE) are more actionable than flat lists
